IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 120520 120520 S0926-860X(25)00421-1 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120520 The Authors Fig. 1 H2-TPR curves for the pre-oxidized 1.0 % Fe-CHA (blue), 1.7 % Fe-CHA (lilac), 2.5 % Fe-CHA (pink). Feed: 10 % H2 in Ar, 10 °C/min to 900 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Evolution of the concentration of NO (red), NH3 (black), N2 (blue) without Slow SCR contribution, NO+NH3 feed concentration (dotted red, when the Slow SCR contribution is removed) during NO+NH3 reduction. Experimental conditions: NO = 500 ppm, NH₃ = 500 ppm, T = 330 °C (He carrier, Ar tracer, GHSV = 266,250 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1) A) 1.0 % Fe-CHA B) 1.7 % Fe-CHA C) 2.5 % Fe-CHA. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Concentration profiles of NO and N2 during NO+NH3 reduction on the three Fe-CHA samples after pre-oxidation with 8 % v/v O2 (gray lines) and with 500 ppm NO₂ + 8 % v/v O₂ (NO red line, N2 blue line); the colored areas are the difference between the two pre-oxidation methods; (He carrier, Ar tracer, GHSV= 266,250 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1). Fe-exchanged zeolite catalysts have recently raised interest due to their higher de-N2O activity compared to Cu-CHA. However, no methodology is currently available to assess their active species and redox properties under real conditions. Herein we investigate Fe-CHA catalysts coupling Transient Response Methods, previously used to investigate Cu-CHA, and Operando FT-IR, with the aim to gain insights in the Fe active species and their behavior under different reactive conditions. Since Fe is well reported in literature to undergo a redox cycle between oxidized and reduced forms, the analysis was divided in two sections focused on reducing and oxidizing methods. From H2-TPR and NO+NH3 reductive protocols, different responses compared to Cu-CHA were observed, evidencing that oxidation of Fe-CHA is less effective. Concerning oxidative protocols, NO2 adsorption/desorption was identified as a key protocol for the titration of active Fe species, as NO2 was stored as nitrate every two iron sites regardless of the speciation. This result was supported by Operando FT-IR tests. The NO2 ads/des protocol was replicated on pre-reduced catalysts, revealing the strong ability of NO2 to oxidize Fe sites, redisperse them and use them as storage sites. Finally, transient N2O decomposition runs, followed by NO+NH3 reduction or TPD, were used to probe Fe-CHA sites. These experiments confirmed the strong oxidizing power of N2O, close to NO2 and superior to O2, showing also how the stability of the stored oxygen, strictly linked with the auto-reduction of the catalysts, as well as the Fe oxidation state, were dependent on the N2O decomposition temperature. Graphical Abstract Keywords Transient response methods Fe-CHA catalysts NH3-SCR N2O Decomposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Abatement of nitrogen oxides (NOx) still represents an important challenge for the automotive industry. Due to the stricter and stricter regulations and the importance of controlling the emission of pollutants, especially N2O, which has a Global Warming Potential approximately 310 times higher than CO2, it is clearly key to keep investigating and improving exhaust gas aftertreatment systems [1–4]. Ammonia-SCR (NH3-SCR) represents the best available technology for Diesel engines, allowing to reduce NOx into harmless N2 molecules according to the main reaction R1, also called Standard SCR [5–7]: (R1) 2NH3 + 2NO + ½O2 → 2N2 + 3H2O State of the art catalysts for these systems are copper-exchanged chabazites (Cu-CHA) [8–11], however, recent interest has been sparked for iron-exchanged chabazites (Fe-CHAs). These materials present a series of advantages among which higher selectivity to nitrogen, elevated SCR activity at the higher temperatures, high sulfur resistance and on top very high de-N2O ability [12–15]. One of the main differences, compared with Cu-based chabazite, even at low loadings, is the higher amount of active species present in Fe-CHAs. In fact, while for Cu-CHA the active NH3-SCR species precursors are regarded as Z2Cu2 + and ZCu2+OH, with the possible presence of CuxOy clusters, iron-exchanged zeolites are associated with a much wider variety: different authors have proposed mononuclear (e.g., Fe(OH)2+) and binuclear (e.g., (HO-Fe-O-Fe-OH)2+) Fe complexes as active species for SCR, but also the role of oligomeric species and clusters in SCR is still debated [16,17]. While understanding the nature of the active species is critical for the design of SCR catalysts and their improvement, it is well understood from the literature, where several works on Fe-ZSM-5, Fe-FER and Fe-MOR have been published together with just a few on Fe-CHA, that no established methodology is currently capable of identifying and quantifying the active species under conditions close to the real ones [18–24]. In this context Transient Response Methods (TRMs) represent a valuable possibility. These methods have been employed in previous works to titrate and identify the different active species in Cu-CHA catalysts. They can be readily implemented using a simple flow reactor, which also enables easy adjustment and variation of the reaction conditions [25–27]. In this paper we present the first application of such methods to the investigation of the active Fe sites in NH3-SCR over Fe-CHA systems. Since NH3-SCR is reported to undergo a redox cycle over Fe-CHA [28,29], the investigation was divided in reducing methods, i.e., experiments involving mixtures that reduce Fe, and oxidizing methods, which, on the contrary, involved molecules able to oxidize the Fe active sites. The first chosen protocol was an isothermal NO+NH3 reduction transient, which enables to fully titrate Cu(II) sites in Cu-CHA, showing a 1:1:1 proportion between the amounts of NO consumed, N2 produced and reduced Cu ions in the sample, which in the case of a sample pre-treated with O2, correspond to all the Cu present in the sample [30]. NO+NH3 transients were repeated on Fe-CHA samples with the aim to investigate the Fe reduction and assess if the same test could be used to titrate iron sites. The analysis on the reducibility of Fe-CHA sites was completed using H2-TPR and Operando FT-IR low temperature NO adsorption tests. Moving on to the oxidizing methods, a TRM protocol was employed starting from the works of Villamaina et al. [27] and Colombo et al. [31]: isothermal NO2 adsorption on a pre-oxidized sample followed by Temperature Programmed Desorption (NO2 ads/des). This protocol was previously used for Cu-CHA to characterize the speciation of Cu(II) in the different samples, since there is a 1:1 ratio between the NO2 observed in the TPD step and the ZCu2+(OH) present in the sample [27]. Seen this result and considering the well-known enhancing effect of NO2 on the Fe-zeolites activity (e.g., in Fast SCR conditions) and its strong oxidizing potential, the protocol was replicated here to investigate Fe-CHA. The tests were also coupled with Operando FT-IR measurements. Finally, in order to investigate the oxidation of Fe, a new transient response method based on the N2O decomposition was implemented. Generally, the decomposition of N2O is well known to proceed through a redox mechanism in which Fe sites cycle between oxidized and reduced states, forming N2 and O2 as follows (reaction R2) [32]: (R2) N2 O → N2 + ½O2 It is often reported and widely accepted that Fe sites are oxidized by N2O during the initial step, when the cleavage of the N₂-O bond leads to the release of nitrogen and the storage of -O on the catalyst. Starting from this consideration N2O decomposition, coupled with NO+NH3 reduction and TPD steps, was used to investigate the effect of N2O as an oxidant on the active sites of Fe-CHA samples. 2 Materials and methods The experimental work was performed over three model Fe−CHA catalyst samples, provided by Johnson Matthey (JM), characterized by the same Silica-to-Alumina Ratio (SAR) and by increasing iron loadings, namely 1.0, 1.7 and 2.5 % w/w according to ICP analysis. Such loadings were selected to investigate systematically how the Fe speciation is impacted by gradually increasing the Fe amount up to values representative of industrial catalysts. The parent zeolite, H-CHA, was also used as an additional sample to investigate the adsorption of NO2. The catalyst samples were tested in the powder form (48 mg, sieved to 120–140 mesh to avoid mass transfer limitations), loaded in a quartz microflow reactor (i.d. = 6 mm) diluted up to 130 mg with cordierite powder of the same mesh size. The tests performed on the experimental rig, whose detailed description can be found at [28,33], were all run at a GHSV of 266,250 Ncm3 h−1 gcat − 1. Helium was selected as a carrier gas to enable measurement of the N2 evolution, while Argon was used as a tracer. The species concentrations were measured by a FT-IR gas analyser (Bruker MATRIX-MG2) and a Mass Spectrometer (MS, Hiden QGA). For the Hydrogen-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) tests a greater load of pelletized catalyst was used (∼300 mg) loaded in a U-shaped sample holder. In this case, the tests were run on a Micromeritics AutoChem II unit in the JM laboratories. The catalyst was firstly pre-oxidized with 5 % O2 in He flow (10,000 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1), then the temperature was raised at 10 °C/min up to 500 °C and then lowered to 40 °C. After purging with He the temperature was lowered to −50 °C and held for 10 min. Finally, TPR was carried out in 10 % H2 in Ar with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. For H2-TPR we used a standard Johnson Matthey protocol: this is the reason behind the choice of starting the test from such a low temperature, even if in Fe-CHA the Fe reduction is known to occur above room temperature. Moreover, the initial temperature for H2-TPR was verified not having an impact on the reducibility of Fe. Operando FT-IR tests were also performed in the JM laboratories on a thin catalyst disk of ∼15 mg using a rig equipped with a IR detector cell (FT-IR spectrometer: Bruker Vertex80, with MCT detector). The sample was placed in the cell (high temperature transmission cell:#CXX, Aabspec) between two KBr windows. The spectra were acquired with a 2 cm−1 resolution, and an average of 128 scans. The evolution of the species was monitored with a Pfifer MS, He was the carrier gas, Kr was used as a tracer and the selected GHSV was 166,667 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1. The investigation of Fe-CHA with Transient Response Methods (TRMs) relied on methodologies that involve the reduction and the oxidation of Fe. Starting from the reducing tests, NO+NH₃ reduction protocols were performed similarly to what done in previous works on Cu-CHA catalysts [8,30,34–36]. The pre-oxidation of the catalyst was run at 550 °C for 1 h with 8 % v/v O2 alone or with 8 % O2 and 500 ppm of NO2 (followed by 15 min in O2 only). 500 ppm of NO2 were fed with 8 % of oxygen since having O2 in the gas flow shifted the equilibrium of the reaction NO2 ↔ NO + ½ O2 towards NO2 enabling a higher NO2 concentration in the gas compared to the case of pure NO2 feed. Once the catalyst was oxidized, the temperature was lowered to 330 °C. Then, the oxygen flow was cut from the feed and, following a 10 min He purge, the reduction step was performed: 500 ppm of NO and 500 ppm of NH₃ were fed to the reactor. Finally, in analogy with previous work, the integrals of NO consumption and N2 production were computed. Another similar reducing test was performed on the 2.5 % Fe sample to investigate the oxidation state of the catalyst after a high temperature reduction: 500 ppm of NO and 500 ppm of NH₃ were fed to the reactor for one hour at 550 °C, then one hour purge in He was used to desorb any stored ammonia. Then, the temperature was lowered to 330 °C and 500 ppm of NO and 500 ppm of NH₃ were fed to the reactor for one hour. Also in this case the integral consumption of NO and production of nitrogen were calculated for the isothermal reduction at 330 °C. In NO adsorption tests with Operando FT-IR, time-resolved FT-IR spectra were collected in transmission mode to investigate the effect of three pre-treatments: 10 % v/v O2 at 500 °C, 4 % v/v H2 at 350 °C and 1000 ppm of NO and of NH₃ at 330 °C. Specifically for the first test, ammonia was isothermally fed for one hour in presence of oxygen to store it on the catalyst, then it was removed from the gas and NO was fed for one hour and then a temperature ramp was started at 10 °C/min up to 550 °C in He to clean the catalyst. After each pre-treatment the system temperature was lowered to 30 °C, purged in He for 15 min and then 1000 ppm of NO were fed to the catalyst. The IR spectra shown in this work were subtracted from the background spectrum, which was recorded just before the start of each individual NO adsorption step in He at the adsorption temperature. The investigation continued using TRMs focused on the oxidation of the Fe-CHA catalysts. Two protocols were adopted: (i) NO2 adsorption + TPD, used to investigate Cu-CHA catalysts in previous works [27,31] and (ii) N2O decomposition. After a pre-oxidation with 8 % v/v O2, 1 h at 550 °C, NO2 adsorption was performed at 150 °C (inlet feed: 500 ppm of NO2), then a TPD test was run (15 °C/min, 150 °C to 550 °C). The same experiment was also repeated after pre-reduction with 500 ppm of NO and 500 ppm of NH3 for 1 h at 550 °C, followed by a 1 h purge in He after which the temperature was lowered to 150 °C. The NO2 adsorption + TPD test, with oxygen pre-treatment, was repeated investigating the catalysts with Operando FT-IR. During the experiments the NO2 concentration was 1000 ppm and the GHSV was the same used for Operando FT-IR experiments: 166,667 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1. N2O decomposition experiments were run starting with a pre-reduction with 500 ppm of NO and 500 ppm of NH3, for 1 h at 550 °C, then the temperature was lowered to 330, 380 or 430 °C and the N2O decomposition was performed feeding 500 ppm of N2O. After this stage, either a TPD ramp at 15 °C/min was performed from the decomposition temperature up to 550 °C (He carrier, GHSV = 266,250 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1), or a NO+NH3 reduction step, where 500 ppm of NO and of NH3 were fed isothermally at 330 °C for 1 h and 20 min (He carrier, GHSV = 266,250 Ncm3 h−1 gcat −1). Specifically, the NO+NH3 reduction test was run on all Fe-CHA samples after the N2O decomposition transient at 330 °C (to also explore the effect of the temperature, it was also replicated after the N2O decomposition at 380 and 430 °C on the intermediate 1.7 % Fe sample) to investigate the temperature effect on the oxidation state of the catalysts and on the reduction step. Finally, like for the reduction tests, the integrals of NO consumption and of N2 production were computed. To investigate the effect of the oxidation with O2 two final tests on the 2.5 % sample were performed: 8 % v/v O2, 1 h at 550 °C were fed to the catalyst, then the temperature was lowered to either 150 °C, temperature at which NO2 ads/des was performed, or to 330 °C, i.e., the temperature at which the reduction and also N2O decomposition were performed. Following this step, oxygen was removed from the feed stream and the temperature was ramped up to 550 °C, at 10 °C/min in He flow. The evolution of oxygen was monitored during the ramp. The investigation on the effect of pure oxygen was performed on the 2.5 % Fe sample, i.e., the one characterized by the highest Fe loading. Since this high loading catalyst would store only a limited amount of O2 at 150 °C and no oxygen at all at 330 °C, it would be expected that samples with lower Fe loadings, which have a smaller number of sites, would also be unable to store oxygen. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reducing methods Fig. 1 shows H2-TPR results for the 1.0, 1.7 and 2.5 % Fe-CHA samples. The three catalysts showed a high peak of H2 consumption centered around 300 °C. According to the literature, this is associated with the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ usually located around 327 °C and the reduction of Fe2O3 around 347 °C. For the 2.5 % sample also a higher temperature peak was observed which can be associated with the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO [37]. The integral H2 consumption was calculated and consequently the H/Fe molar ratio, as shown in Table 1. It is immediately evident that the H/Fe ratios are below unity. This result could be explained either by the three samples not being fully reduced by hydrogen during H2-TPR, or by the presence of reduced iron prior to the H2 TPR, caused by the auto reduction of the catalyst (reaction R3) [38,39]. (R3) 4Fe3+ + 2O2− → 4Fe2+ + O2 After this first analysis, the NO+NH3 reduction protocol was implemented to investigate the redox state of the catalyst. The evolution of the concentrations of NO, N2 and NH3 during the tests is shown in Fig. 2: the evolution of N2 and the consumption NO and NH3 were observed, similar to the tests performed on Cu-CHA [27]. Differently from Cu-CHA, however, after one hour the concentration of NO and ammonia were not yet stabilized at the feed level but approached a steady state less than 500 ppm. The same was true for N2 produced which did not go back to zero. This behavior was attributed to the co-participation of NO and NH3 in the Slow SCR reaction[40], catalyzed by the reduced Fe sites. In order to decouple the effects of Fe reduction and Slow SCR and calculate the integral NO consumption (NOcons) and N2 production (N2,prod) in the reduction step, the Slow SCR contribution was removed, both lowering the NO feed concentration to the final steady state value and also lowering the N2 concentration to zero at steady state, i.e., subtracting the final steady state N2 concentration profile. However, after the removal of the Slow SCR contribution, when calculating the NOcons/Fe and N2,prod/Fe molar ratios, differently from Cu-CHA, there was no 1:1:1 correlation between the total amount of metal in the samples and the calculated integral amounts of NO consumption and of N2 production. The NO/Fe ratio was in fact always less than 50 % as shown in Table 2. Similarly to H2-TPR, this behavior could be attributed to the oxidizing step, where O2 was not capable to prevent the catalyst from going through auto-reduction. To account for the difficulty of Fe sites to remain oxidized, the test was repeated after pre-treating the catalyst with a stronger oxidizing mixture: 500 ppm of NO2 with 8 % v/v of O2. In this case, as shown in Fig. 3, there was an evident increase in the reactivity of the samples during the reduction step. In fact, the NO consumption and N2 production were much higher, as shown in Table 3. However, it is important to say that, despite the strong enhancing effect of the pre-oxidation with NO2, the NO/Fe ratio never approached 100 % for all the samples. Nevertheless, this investigation highlighted the stronger potential of NO2 in oxidizing Fe sites in presence of O2, compared to oxygen alone. Operando FT-IR – NO adsorption experiments, which are generally utilized for the identification of Fe2+ species in Fe-zeolites, were carried out with the aim to investigate the reduced iron in the samples[41]. After pre-treatment, the catalyst was cooled to 30 °C and the IR spectra of the adsorbed species were recorded at 30 °C. The collected spectra are shown in Fig. 4. A strong band at 1880 cm−1 was observed on all the samples, attributed to mononitrosyl Fe2+ (Fe2+−NO) complexes[29]. Interestingly this band was present also after the pre-treatment in oxygen, further confirming the idea that oxygen could not leave the catalyst in a fully oxidized condition due to either its limited oxidizing power or due to the inability of oxygen to fight auto-reduction of the Fe sites. Moreover, the experiments showed that the intensity of Fe2+−NO after H2 or NO+ NH3 treatment was higher than after the O2 treatment, indicating that previously oxidized Fe species could be reduced by hydrogen or by the NO+NH3 mixture already at ∼300 °C [32,42]. Finally, when the reducibility of Fe was investigated feeding NO+NH3 at higher temperatures, the 2.5 % Fe-CHA sample showed a higher peak of Fe2+-NO after the NO+NH3 temperature ramp to 500 °C, as shown in Fig. 5A. This aspect was also investigated with the NO+NH3 reduction protocol at 330 °C after a pre-reduction with NO+NH3 at 550 °C. The results from the NO+NH3 reduction at 330 °C showed that after the pre-treatment at 550 °C with NO and ammonia almost all the Fe that was participating in the low temperature reduction (i.e., when the catalyst was pre-treated with O2), was already reduced in the previous high temperature step. This was evident from the integral consumption of NO and N2 which was less than 2 µmol (NO/Fe < 9 %). 3.2 Oxidizing methods In literature, the presence of NO2 under SCR conditions (Fast SCR) is often reported to have a positive effect on the DeNOx activity over various Fe-exchanged zeolites [43,44]. This is in line with the enhancing effect observed on the NO+NH3 protocol after the NO2+O2 pre-oxidation step, but leaves an open question on how NO2 could be interacting with Fe sites. Starting from these considerations, the NO2 adsorption/desorption protocol was employed to elucidate the effect of NO2 on the Fe active sites. The NO2 adsorption + TPD protocol described in the Materials and Methods section was performed on the three Fe-CHA samples as well as on the H-CHA sample. As also observed in previous works, during the NO2 adsorption step NO2 was stored on the sample, the NO2 outlet concentration reaching the feed level after a few minutes, while an initial instant peak of NO production was observed, which then decreased to zero. The initial NO release (red line in Fig. 6, with calculated integral amount in Table 4) has been reported by several authors and is ascribed to the adsorption of NO2 on metal sites following a two-step mechanism, which includes firstly the disproportionation of NO2 to form nitrites and nitrates on the surface, followed by the oxidation of nitrites to nitrates by NO2 and the consequent release of NO [31]. This aspect was further confirmed considering that on the H-CHA, where no iron sites are present, no evolution of NO was observed while only a small quantity of NO2 was adsorbed (Fig. 6 A)). Fig. 7 shows the NO2 desorbed from all the samples during the TPD step plotted against the temperature. As the temperature was increased, the evolution of NO2 was observed over all the tested catalysts characterized by a single peak centered around 300 °C, suggesting the presence of similarly stable nitrate species on all the samples. Table 4 reports the calculated integral amounts of NO2 adsorbed, physisorbed and desorbed during the TPD, along with the corresponding Fe/NO2 TPD molar ratios. Interestingly, Fe/NO2 was ∼2 for all the tested Fe-CHA samples. This could suggest that each NO2 molecule was stored in the form of bridging nitrate (M-NO3-M), i.e., every two molecules of Fe, regardless of the Fe speciation. To confirm the presence of bridging nitrates on the catalyst surface, the FT-IR bands that evolve during NO2 adsorption ( Fig. 8) on the different catalysts were compared. The main features observed after the NO2 adsorption and the purge in He at 150 °C were the ones associated with the presence of nitrates located at 1612 cm−1and 1575 cm−1 [45]. Mihaylov reported the association of these bands with bridging nitrates, which further supports the hypothesis of the presence of two metal sites every nitrate stored [46]. Finally, the H-CHA sample also showed bands associated with the formation of nitrates, however, while there seemed to be a peak at around 1575 cm−1, the band at 1480 cm−1 was not observed in Fe-CHA samples. This could be considered further evidence of the presence of specific nitrates when the Fe is present in the zeolite. When the NO2 adsorption tests were repeated starting from a pre-reduced condition, i.e., after pre-treating the catalyst at high temperature with NO+NH3, it was clear that the initial catalyst redox state had a strong impact on the NO2 adsorption. For all samples, in fact, as shown in Fig. 9, a much greater quantity of NO2 was adsorbed and of NO was released during the initial part of the test compared to the catalysts pre-treated with oxygen (see calculated integrals in Table 4). An even greater difference between the two tests was evident for the NO2 TPD curves. Fig. 10 compares the NO2 TPD curves for the four samples: it is clear that the reducing pre-treatment leads to an increased amount of stored nitrates and also to the formation of a few less stable species on the 1.7 % and 2.5 % samples, highlighted by the appearance of two smaller peaks at 200 °C. A similar behavior was also observed by Colombo et al. on Cu zeolite catalysts and ascribed to the formation of less stable adsorbates, such as nitrites or less stable nitrates [31]. Table 4 shows the Fe/NO2 TPD ratios: contrarily to what observed for the samples pre-treated with O2, in this case the ratios are < 2, suggesting that when the catalysts were strongly reduced, NO2 was not stored every two metals (bridged nitrates) but it chose different configurations depending on the Fe loading. The greater amount of NO produced in the experiments suggests that NO2 would firstly oxidize the Fe sites and then get stored as nitrates on the oxidized sites. Moreover, the increased Fe/NO2 ratio on all the samples suggests that the nitrates were stored differently with respect to the pre-oxidized case, as if NO2 had led to the re-dispersion of the actives sites, storing onto each Fe sites on the 1.0 % sample, and in a more heterogenous way at higher Fe loadings [31,47]. N2O decomposition was used as a last TRM to investigate the Fe-CHA catalysts. This was the only protocol that had not been previously applied to investigate Cu-CHA systems. It was specifically introduced to study Fe-CHA due to the known capability of this molecule to oxidize Fe [48,49]. Fig. 11 shows the evolution of N2O, N2 and O2 on the three Fe-CHA samples at 330 °C. All the three samples showed an immediate consumption of N2O which mirrored a nitrogen production peak. On the contrary, oxygen exhibited much slower and delayed dynamics, being observed a few seconds later than the nitrogen signal. Following the N2O feed step, NO+NH3 reduction was performed on all the samples at 330 °C (the same reduction protocol used in the previous section): in all cases consumption of NO and NH3 and production of N2 were observed, thus confirming the oxidizing potential of N2O on the pre-reduced Fe-CHA catalysts. Fig. 12 shows the bar plot of the NO/Fe ratio estimated from the integral consumption of NO during the NO+NH3 reduction step after the N2O feed step compared to the results obtained after the pre-oxidation with O2, (as shown above) and the pre oxidation with 8 % v/v of O2 and 500 ppm of NO2. From this comparison it is evident that exposure to both N2O and NO2 + O2 led to a much higher consumption of NO than with O2 alone, for which the consumption of NO was less than 50 % of the total iron sites. The decision to compare the value of NO/Fe after N2O decomposition at 330 °C to the reduction performed after the oxygen pre-treatment is justified considering that when O2 was used to pre-treat the catalyst it was fed at 550 °C but then the temperature was lowered to 330 °C still in oxygen flow, leaving the catalyst exposed to oxygen at 330 °C. To further clarify how the auto reduction of the active sites played a role in determining the oxidation state of Fe, the experiment was repeated on the 1.7 % Fe-CHA sample performing the N2O decomposition protocol at different temperatures. In this case N2O was decomposed at increasing temperatures, then the oxidation state of the catalyst was evaluated by an isothermal NO+NH3 reduction step at 330 °C. The results in Table 5 clearly show that the temperature at which N2O was fed influenced the oxidation state of Fe. In fact, while NO/Fe was 67 % when N2O was fed at 330 °C, 66 % when the decomposition temperature was 380 °C, it decreased to 58 % when the temperature was 430 °C, further dropping to 38 % when the decomposition was performed at the highest temperature, 550 °C. To further investigate the redox state of the catalysts, a TPD was run following the N2O decomposition steps at 330, 380 and 430 °C. Interestingly, on all the samples we observed ( Fig. 13) the release of O2 as the temperature was increased. Moreover, the amount of O2 desorbed decreased as the temperature at which N2O was fed increased. This behavior is in line with the previous results obtained with NO+NH3 reduction on the 1.7 % Fe sample, where the amount of Fe participating in the reduction was decreasing as the temperature of the N2O feed was increasing. This clearly points out that auto reduction of the Fe-CHA catalyst is closely linked with the temperature at which the catalyst is investigated, showing also the difficulty of keeping the catalyst in an oxidized form. Furthermore, the influence of N2O was also compared to the effect of NO2 on the Fe-CHA catalysts by analysing the amount of O2 released during the TPDs. In fact, the O2 evolution was observed and monitored during the NO2 desorption step of the experiment on the pre-reduced catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 14 (green curve), in the case of NO2 adsorption the desorption of oxygen was observed firstly at lower temperatures in correspondence of the decomposition of nitrates [31], then also a second O2 peak was observed above 380 °C. Interestingly, this second peak is superimposed to the peak associated with the oxygen evolution in the TPD after the N2O decomposition transient at 330 °C (pink curve in Fig. 14). In both tests there was a distinct oxygen peak starting from ∼380 °C and peaking at 450 °C. This behavior is in line with the much stronger oxidizing potential of the two molecules compared to O2 alone. A final confirmation of the scarce ability of O2 to leave the catalyst in a strongly oxidized state was collected running two O2 treatment tests on the high Fe loading sample, 2.5 % Fe-CHA. When 8 % v/v of O2 was fed to the catalyst at 550 °C and then the temperature was lowered to 330 °C, as done before the reduction protocol, there was no oxygen evolution during the temperature ramp to indicate consequently no storage of oxygen on the catalyst ( Fig. 15). Instead, when the temperature was lowered to 150 °C a small storage of O2 was observed, which was however characterized by an integral less than 1 µmol and much smaller than the one observed after NO2 desorption. 4 Conclusions In this work a set of Fe-CHA catalysts were investigated coupling transient response methods with Operando FT-IR. While for Cu-CHA catalysts transient tests can be used to titrate the amount of reducible Cu, quantify the fraction of oxidized active sites and investigate their speciation, our data indicate that in the case of Fe-CHA the same protocols cannot be used directly for the same purposes, but they need to be revised and adjusted to the more complicated systems represented by Feexchanged chabazites. The main challenge with Fe-CHA, other than the well documented coexistence of a broader spectrum of Fe active sites, was the very different ability of the active species to be oxidized and remain in an oxidized form without going through auto-reduction. Based on the independent study of the reduction and oxidation steps, the following results and conclusions can be drawn: • Concerning the reducibility of Fe sites, H2-TPR and NO+NH3 reduction tests showed that only a fraction of Fe < 50 % was participating in the reduction step. • When the catalyst was pre-oxidized with a NO2+O2 mixture, a strong increment of the NO consumption in the NO+NH3 reduction tests was observed. However, despite the increased NO/Fe ratio, a N2:NO:Fe molar ratio = 1: 1:1 was never detected, as instead observed for Cu-CHA catalysts. • It can be concluded that the NO+NH3 reduction test is not suitable to titrate all the redox sites of Fe-CHA, but it could be used instead as a methodology that rapidly informs on the effect of the different pre-treatments on the redox state of the Fe sites. In fact, we used it to clearly show that adding 500 ppm of NO2 to the oxidizing mixture strongly increased the oxidation state of iron. It also evidenced the inability of oxygen alone to fully oxidize iron, which was cited in literature but never clearly demonstrated and which can be linked to the higher activity of Fe zeolites under Fast SCR conditions compared to Standard SCR. • To fully support this conclusion, FT-IR NO adsorption tests showed the presence of Fe2+ also on the samples pre-treated with oxygen, further confirming the inability of O2 to leave the catalyst fully oxidized. • Another interesting observation linked to the activity of Fe zeolites is the difficulty for Fe to be fully reduced at lower temperatures, observed when reducing at 330 °C and 550 °C with NO+NH3: this can explain the 100 °C difference between Cu-CHA and Fe-CHA in the Standard SCR activity data collected by Metkar et al. [50]. Differently from Fe-CHA, in fact, Cu-CHA is fast and fully reduced by NO+NH3 already at 150 °C [30]. After the investigation of the Fe reduction step, the attention was focused on the study of the active Fe sites involved in Fe oxidation: given the strong oxidation activity of NO2, the NO2 adsorption+TPD protocol was applied to investigate the interaction of NO2 with the catalyst. • NO2 was adsorbed onto Fe-CHA as one nitrate every two Fe sites, regardless of the Fe species distribution in the tested catalyst samples. Accordingly, this specific transient test was able to titrate all the Fe sites present in the catalyst samples. • To further investigate the interaction of NO2 with the catalyst, the same experiment was repeated after reducing the catalysts in NO+NH3 at high temperature. This further revealed the oxidizing ability of NO2, which firstly oxidized Fe, then was stored while re-distributing the sites, not adsorbing every two Fe sites like on the O2 pre-treated sample but with different proportions depending on the Fe loading. Finally, catalytic N2O decomposition was used as a novel, specific transient response method to study Fe-CHA systems. • From the first tests it emerged that temperature had a promoting effect on the N2O decomposition activity of the Fe-CHA catalysts. This finding was in line with the following investigation of the oxidation state of the catalyst. In fact, the NO+NH₃ protocol after the N₂O feed step revealed that at lower temperatures N₂O leaves the catalyst in an oxidized state. However, at higher temperatures the NO consumption during the reduction step was significantly less due to the auto-reduction of the catalyst being favored at elevated temperatures. • The oxidation state of the catalyst was also examined by means of TPD tests, during which the O₂ evolution was monitored. The oxygen peak closely resembled the desorption of O₂ observed after NO₂ adsorption but significantly differed from the TPD following an O₂-only pre-treatment. This further confirmed the similar oxidation strength of both NO2 and N2O, counterbalancing the auto-reduction even at low temperatures, reinforcing the concept that O₂ alone is not a strong enough oxidant to fully involve and maintain most of the Fe sites in an oxidized state. In summary, Fe-CHA catalysts were extensively investigated coupling transient response methods and Operando FT-IR. The investigation was performed starting from previous successful studies of Cu-CHA catalysts, but clearly showed that Fe-CHA and Cu-CHA cannot be treated as similar systems, so that the methodologies developed for the Cu-zeolite catalysts had to be adapted to the more complex Fe-CHA systems: an important conclusion of the present work is in fact that the same protocols cannot be used directly for the same purposes. Nevertheless, such transient protocols enabled to effectively gain insight into the Fe catalyst features and to shed light onto the redox behavior of Fe-CHA systems, specifically on the effects of different oxidants and on the extent of the catalyst auto-reduction at different temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Fe-exchanged zeolite catalysts have recently raised interest due to their higher de-N2O activity compared to Cu-CHA. However, no methodology is currently available to assess their active species and redox properties under real conditions. Herein we investigate Fe-CHA catalysts coupling Transient Response Methods, previously used to investigate Cu-CHA, and Operando FT-IR, with the aim to gain insights in the Fe active species and their behavior under different reactive conditions. Since Fe is well reported in literature to undergo a redox cycle between oxidized and reduced forms, the analysis was divided in two sections focused on reducing and oxidizing methods. From H2-TPR and NO+NH3 reductive protocols, different responses compared to Cu-CHA were observed, evidencing that oxidation of Fe-CHA is less effective. Concerning oxidative protocols, NO2 adsorption/desorption was identified as a key protocol for the titration of active Fe species, as NO2 was stored as nitrate every two iron sites regardless of the speciation. This result was supported by Operando FT-IR tests. The NO2 ads/des protocol was replicated on pre-reduced catalysts, revealing the strong ability of NO2 to oxidize Fe sites, redisperse them and use them as storage sites. Finally, transient N2O decomposition runs, followed by NO+NH3 reduction or TPD, were used to probe Fe-CHA sites. These experiments confirmed the strong oxidizing power of N2O, close to NO2 and superior to O2, showing also how the stability of the stored oxygen, strictly linked with the auto-reduction of the catalysts, as well as the Fe oxidation state, were dependent on the N2O decomposition temperature.
